# Die Replikationskrise {{< iconify fa6-solid:circle-exclamation >}}

## Die Replikationskrise {{< iconify fa6-solid:circle-exclamation >}}

Leider sind »Replizierbarkeit/Replicability« und »Reproduzierbarkeit/Reproducibility« keine einheitlich genutzten sondern teilweise sogar komplementär genutzen Begriffe [@barba; @reproduc2019]. Lasst uns daher folgende Definitionen festlegen:

|              |           | Data               |               |
|:-------------|:----------|:-------------------|:--------------|
|              |           | Same               | Different     |
| **Analysis** | Same      | ***Reproducible*** | Replicable    |
|              | Different | Robust             | Generalisable |

## Die Replikationskrise {{< iconify fa6-solid:circle-exclamation >}}

Viele meta-scientifische Studien liefern Evidenz für die Annahme Replikationsraten weit unter 95%:

-   Psychologie: \~36% [@opensciencecollaboration2015]
-   Preclinical Cancer Biology: \~ 46% [@errington2021]
-   Experimental Econ: \~61% [@camerer2016]
-   Social science experiments in **Nature** and **Science**:\~62% [@camerer2018]

> Zudem zeigen selbst die erfolgreichen Replikationen in etwa 50% der Originaleffektstärke

## Ableitung der Ziele für heute {{< iconify fa6-solid:bullseye >}} {.smaller}
:::: {.columns .v-center-container}
::: {.column width="40%"}
$$\alpha = \text{Falsch-Positiv-Rate} = .05$$ 

<center>und</center>

$$\text{Replikationraten} << .95$$
:::
::: {.column width="20%"}
<center><br><br><br>**aber**</center>
:::
::: {.column width="33%"}
![Hohe Vorhersagekraft von Prediction Markets und Surveys für Replizierbarkeit in in @camerer2018](img/prediction_markets_surveys.jpg){#fig-prediction-markets-surveys width="80%"}
:::
::::

> Wenn die Falsch-Positiv-Rate üblicherweise = .05, aber die Replikationsrate ≪ .95, gleichzeitig Prediction Markets und Surveys unter Forschenden Replikationen gut vorhersagen, sollten wir lernen, was diese Vorhersage erlaubt um a) bessere Studien zu planen und b) Studien besser zu bewerten.

# False Positive Psychology 
## False Positive Psychology {{< iconify temaki:maze >}} {.smaller}

Lest die Abstracts »Study 1« und »Study 2« aus Simmons et al. -@simmons2011 auf Seite 1360 [(pdf hier)](img/Simmons_et_al_2011.pdf).  

> Wir alle würden diesen beiden Studien geringe Chancen einräumen, erfolgreich zu replizieren. Warum?

## False Positive Psychology {{< iconify temaki:maze >}} {.smaller}

| Researcher degrees of freedom | *p* <. 1 | *p* < .05 | *p* < .01 |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Situation A: two dependent variables (*r* =.50) | 17.8% | 9.5% | 2.2% |
| Situation B: addition of 10 more observations per cell | 14.5% | 7.7% | 1.6% |
| Situation C: controlling for gender or interaction of gender with treatment | 21.6% | 11.7% | 2.7% |
| Situation D: dropping (or not dropping) one of three conditions | 23.2% | 12.6% | 2.8% |
| Combine Situations A and B | 26.0% | 14.4% | 3.3% |
| Combine Situations A, B, and C | 50.9% | 30.9% | 8.4% |
| Combine Situations A, B, C, and D | 81.5% | 60.7% | 21.5% |

: Zentrale Simulationsergebnisse in Simmons et al. -@simmons2011 {#tbl-simulationen-simmons tbl-colwidths="\[200,30,30,30\]"}

## False Positive Psychology {{< iconify temaki:maze >}} {.smaller}
Um ein Gefühl für die »Researcher Degrees of Freedom« zu bekommen, könnt ihr die in Simmons et al. -@simmons2011 beschriebenen Manipulationen selbst ausprobieren mit der [p-hacker app {{< iconify fa-solid:link >}}](https://shiny.psy.lmu.de/felix/p-hacker/) von Felix Schönbrodt.

# What to do? {{< iconify fa6-solid:arrows-turn-to-dots >}}

## What to do? {{< iconify fa6-solid:arrows-turn-to-dots >}} {.smaller}
»[**Using the same method as in Study 1, we asked ~~20~~ 34 University of Pennsylvania undergraduates to listen** only **to either “When I’m Sixty-Four” by The Beatles or “Kalimba”** or “Hot Potato” by the Wiggles. We conducted our analyses after every session of approximately 10 participants; we did not decide in advance when to terminate data collection. **Then, in an ostensibly unrelated task, they indicated** only **their birth date (mm/dd/yyyy) and** how old they felt, how much they would enjoy eating at a diner, the square root of 100, their agreement with “computers are complicated machines,” their father’s age, **their mother’s age**, whether they would take advantage of an early-bird special, their political orientation, which of four Canadian quarterbacks they believed won an award, how often they refer to the past as “the good old days,” and their gender. **We used father’s age to control for variation in baseline age across participants.**    
**An ANCOVA revealed the predicted effect: According to their birth dates, people were nearly a year-and-a-half younger after listening to “When I’m Sixty-Four” (adjusted M = 20.1 years) rather than to “Kalimba” (adjusted M = 21.5 years), F(1, 17) = 4.92, p = .040.** Without controlling for father’s age, the age difference was smaller and did not reach significance (Ms = 20.3 and 21.2, respectively), F(1, 18) = 1.01, p = .33.«]{style="font-size: 0.95em;"}
